references: In table 1, results on CIFAR-10 are shown for r={0,180}ğ‘Ÿ0180r=\{0,180\}. Accuracies are reported both for independent and common weight initialization for the client models. In centralized federated learning, it is known that a common initialization of client models is important for federated averaging to work (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). Meanwhile, our results suggest that a common initialization is not necessary in order for the different algorithms to reach a high accuracy in decentralized federated learning. Further, the proposed method pens achieves an accuracy that is higher than all baselines and close to the performance of Oracle with perfect information of client data distributions ğ’Ÿirâ€‹(x)subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¥\mathcal{D}^{r}_{i}(x). In table 2 we see that pens outperforms the baselines also in the case of r={0,90,180,270}ğ‘Ÿ090180270r=\{0,90,180,270\}.

In centralized federated learning, it is known that a common initialization of client models is important for federated averaging to work (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). Meanwhile, our results suggest that a common initialization is not necessary in order for the different algorithms to reach a high accuracy in decentralized federated learning. Further, the proposed method pens achieves an accuracy that is higher than all baselines and close to the performance of Oracle with perfect information of client data distributions ğ’Ÿirâ€‹(x)subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¥\mathcal{D}^{r}_{i}(x). references: The parameter nsampledsubscriptğ‘›sampledn_{\text{sampled}} in step 1 of pens decides for each client how many other client models to sample at every communication round, and mğ‘šm decides how many of the top-performing (lowest loss) to merge with. Experiments were carried out to study how sensitive pens  is to the choice of these hyperparameters. In table 4 we summarize the results for varying values of these hyperparameters in the setting of 100 clients and 400 training samples per client for CIFAR-10. We note that the test accuracies are relatively stable for different values of nsampledsubscriptğ‘›sampledn_{\text{sampled}} and mğ‘šm. Further, our results suggest that the ratio nsampledmsubscriptğ‘›sampledğ‘š\frac{n_{\text{sampled}}}{m} should not be too large, i.e. if nsampledsubscriptğ‘›sampledn_{\text{sampled}} is increased mğ‘šm should be higher as well. We have noticed in our experiments that if mğ‘šm is set too low relative to nsampledsubscriptğ‘›sampledn_{\text{sampled}}, pens will collapse into always choosing the same few clients and miss to find other peers of the same distribution.

Train set size Precision (%) Recall (%)

references: In table 5 we report for precision (the fraction of clients with the same distribution ğ’Ÿrsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{r} among the selected clients) and recall (the fraction of clients with the same distribution ğ’Ÿrsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{r}) for the peers that pens  selects for each client. Here we report experiments for 100 clients for a different number of training samples per client. We note that the precision of our method is very high and robust to the number of training samples per client. The recall is lower than the precision, but also robust to the number of training samples.
